relation: no frame relay inverse-arp protocol dlci
Enables Frame Relay Inverse ARP for a specific protocol and DLCI pair, only if it was previously disabled.
Disables Frame Relay Inverse ARP for a specific protocol and DLCI pair.
pageTitle: Wide-Area Networking Configuration Guide: Frame Relay, Cisco IOS XE Release 3S - Configuring Frame Relay [Support] - Cisco
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {2038=Frame Relay supports encapsulation of all supported protocols in conformance with RFC 1490, Multiprotocol Interconnect over Frame Relay, allowing interoperability among multiple vendors. Use the IETF form of Frame Relay encapsulation if your device or access server is connected to another vendor’s equipment across a Frame Relay network. IETF encapsulation is supported either at the interface level or on a per-VC basis., 113957=Configures Frame Relay fragmentation for the map class. The fragment_size argument defines the payload size of a fragment; it excludes the Frame Relay headers and any Frame Relay fragmentation header. The valid range is from 16 to 1600 bytes, and the default is 53., 39899=Real-time Transport Protocol (RTP) is a protocol used for carrying packetized audio and video traffic over an IP network. It provides end-to-end network transport functions intended for these real-time traffic applications and multicast or unicast network services. RTP is described in RFC 1889,A Transport Protocol for Real-Time Applications . RTP is not intended for data traffic, which uses TCP or UDP., 173956=Frame Relay supports encapsulation of all supported protocols in conformance with RFC 1490, allowing interoperability between multiple vendors., 10930=software provides the ability to listen in on both DLCI 1023 (cisco LMI) and DLCI 0 (ANSI and ITU) simultaneously., 34111=TCP/IP header compression, as described by RFC 1144, Compressing TCP/IP Headers for Low-Speed Serial Links is designed to improve the efficiency of bandwidth utilization over low-speed serial links. A typical TCP/IP packet includes a 40-byte datagram header. Once a connection is established, the header information is redundant and need not be repeated in every packet that is sent. Reconstructing a smaller header that identifies the connection, indicates the fields that have changed and the amount of change reduces the number of bytes transmitted. The average compressed header is 10 bytes long., 149451=The following configuration provides backward compatibility and interoperability with versions not compliant with RFC 1490. The ietf keyword is used to generate RFC 1490 traffic. This configuration is possible because of the flexibility provided by separately defining each map entry.}
textBeforeTable: You can set various optional counters, intervals, and thresholds to fine-tune the operation of your Local Management Interface data terminal equipment (LMI DTE) and data communications equipment (DCE) devices. Set these attributes by using one or more of the following commands in interface configuration mode: Setting the LMI Polling and Timer Intervals Returns to privileged EXEC mode.     Device(config-if)# end  end Example: Step 5   To disable keepalives on networks that do not utilize LMI, use the no keepalive command. Note    keepalive period Device(config-if)# keepalive 300     Device(config)# int ethernet 0/1   - Valid range is from 0 to 32767. Sets the keepalive interval.   keepalive keepalive period Example: Step 4 Specifies the interface, and enters interface configuration mode.   interface typenumber Example: Step 3
textAfterTable: frame-relay lmi-t392dce  seconds Sets the polling verification timer on a DCE or NNI interface. frame-relay lmi-n391dte  keep-exchanges Sets a full status polling interval on a DTE or NNI interface. frame-relay lmi-n392dte  threshold Sets the DTE or NNI error threshold. frame-relay lmi-n393dte  events Sets the DTE and NNI monitored events count. Configuring MQC-Based Frame Relay Traffic Shaping Specifying a Traffic-Shaping Map Class for the Interface Defining a Map Class with Queueing and Traffic-Shaping Parameters Specifying a Traffic-Shaping Map Class for the Interface To specify a map class for the specified interface, use the following command beginning in interface configuration mode: SUMMARY STEPS
